title: SUFFERING MADE BEARABLE
words:
A special issue on South Africa. Part 1.  Quote from Desmond Tutu's 
guest editorial:  "Our God knows our human condition from inside.  He 
did not shout good advice from a safe distance.  He was embroiled in 
the muck, in the suffering, in the confusion and misunderstanding.  
He was a baby. He was born.  He lived. He died.  He rose again. 
Christ's life says God cared, God still cares, that babies matter, 
that family life matters, that homes matter, that people matter, that 
decent living matters, that relationships matter, and that our 
existence matters--matters so much that God glorified it by becoming 
a human baby.  God be praised."

     "Suffering made bearable" by Desmond Tutu. International 
Christian Digest, Mar 1989.  Page 3.
  Part 2. A biography of Archbishop Desmond Tutu, substantiating the 
claims that he is a thoroughgoing incarnational theologian who claims 
that Christians (with God) must opt for the poor, the powerless, and 
the marginalized, and that such activities are no more subversive 
than the Bible itself. "Desmond Tutu" by Simon Maimela.  Pages 6-8.

  Part 3. The general secretary of the South African Council of 
Churches gives his reasons why anti-communist rhetoric isn't 
convincing in South Africa:  1) Black South Africa has never been 
part of East-West ideological conflict and the related cold war. 2) 
The people who try to sell anti-communism are the oppressors. 3) 
Communist countries have shown themselves willing to assist blacks in 
being free from the apartheid system. The church usually addresses 
"secondary" sin rather than "primary" sin. "The church highlights the 
sinfulness of people who steal-- from their bosses--without 
addressing the sin of those who cause them to be poor--by exploiting 
them at work in the first place."  "Why anti-communist rhetoric won't 
work in South Africa" by Frank Chikane. Pages 9, 10.

  Part 4. A quote from Allan Boesak, moderator of the Dutch Reformed 
Mission Church:  "I want to say this as calmly as I can, Mr. 
Government Minister. You can threaten us all you like. Let your 
security police terrorize our children, come into the streets and 
into our churches and massacre us, because Jesus Christ is Lord.  The 
battle is on, but no government can challenge the living God and 
survive.  That, Mr. Minister, is the good news for the people of God 
and the bad for you. Jesus Christ is Lord." "Demanding God's justice" 
by Allan Boesak. Page 13.

  Part 5. A quote from Tshenuwani Farisani, deputy bishop of the 
Evangelical Lutheran Church in South Africa:  "The apartheid thief is 
13 percent of the population but he wants 87 percent of the oxygen 
for himself and 100 percent of the carbon monoxide for black people.  
Whoever buys from the thief is accessory to the thefts, and 
encourages the profession.  If there were no buyers for the apartheid 
merchandise, the apartheid shop would close down, and the factory of 
racism would declare bankruptcy before humankind and before God." 
"Apartheid shall surely die!" by Tshenuwani Simon Farisani. Pages 14, 
15 Other articles include an interview with Beyers Naude, a white who 
might have become the prime minister of South Africa had he not 
become convinced of the evil of the apartheid, and a debate on 
benefits of U.S. sanctions. "Beyers Naude: love when others hate" by 
Jim Wallis. Pages 16-19. "Should the governments apply sanctions 
against South Africa?" Pages 20, 21.

title: SEX AND THE CHURCH
words:
"The Church refuses to muffle what it regards as Christ's own 
moral standard, but its witness is hobbled by the scandal that 
hundreds of its priests have sexually abused children."

   The Roman Catholic Church in America is divided over issues of sex 
and gender.  Large numbers of members oppose the Church's traditional 
teachings on contraception, abortion rights, ordination of women as 
priests, marriage as an option for priests, premarital sex, and 
homosexuality.  A recent Newsweek poll shows that the majority of 
American Catholics differ with the Vatican's official teaching on 
every one of these issues. Add to this the complication of hundreds 
of priests accused of child molestation, and we see a church in 
turmoil.

   On Pope Paul II's recent visit to the United States, he met for 
the first time with President Clinton, who was strongly supported in 
last fall's election by homosexual and abortion rights advocates, and 
by 44% of Catholic voters.  Yet Catholics, many of whom presumably 
voted for Clinton, are furious over his choice for surgeon general, 
Dr. Joycelyn Elders, an avid prochoicer.

   With the near collapse of the institutions of marriage and the 
family in America over the last 30 years, old norms of sexual 
behavior have also taken a tumble.  Along with shifting sexual mores 
came the mass exodus to the suburbs, where the sense of community 
that once reinforced Church values about sex and marriage has also 
eroded.

   When the papal encyclical "Humanae Vitae" was issued in 1968, most 
Catholics hoped the Vatican would modify its stance on birth control, 
but they were disappointed.  Most married Catholics and numerous 
theologians have taken the view that contraception is a "moral and 
practical necessity."  Rather than uniting Catholics, the Humanae 
Vitae has, for some 25 years, divided the Catholic community on 
issues of sexuality.

   Younger Catholics no longer see Rome as their authority in sexual 
matters.  In addition to divergent views on birth control and 
premarital sex, there is widespread sentiment favoring optional 
celibacy for priests, the ordination of women as priests, and even 
monogamous homosexual marriages.  Issues like the high rates of both 
divorce and teen pregnancy in the U.S., along with concerns about 
AIDS, date rape, and ambiguous gender roles are also major concerns 
of Catholics today.

   In the Church's effort to teach its members high standards of 
sexual behavior, it has been severely hampered by the immoral actions 
of numerous priests accused of child molestation. The scandal, a 
decade in the making, has caused many Catholics to lose their sense 
of trust in their priests and in the Church as a whole.  What has 
made a bad situation even worse is the apparent "cleansing," not of 
priests, but of diocesan personnel records.

   Newsweek's poll found that most Catholics thought the Church had 
treated abusing priests too leniently.  The Church has begun its 
damage control plan:  archdioceses are searching personnel records 
for evidence of abuse, and American emissaries to the Vatican urged 
the defrocking of sexually abusive priests. The Pope responded, 
however, by appointing another commission to "study the issue."

   Many questions arise concerning the connections, if any, between 
the celibate priesthood and child molestation.  All organizations 
that work with youth are vulnerable to child abuse, says Greg Graze, 
spokesman of the Boy Scouts.  While most incidents of abuse within 
churches occur in the Roman Catholic fold, no denomination is 
immune.  Counselors say that pedophilia and ephebophilia (attraction 
to a youngster in puberty) are similar to alcoholism in that 
tendencies can be halted, but never totally cured.

   Writing from a priest's perspective, Andrew Greely (in a followup 
article) notes that celibacy in the priesthood has been honored more 
at some times and places in history than others. It has always been 
difficult to honor the pledge of celibacy, but never impossible.  
Since most documented pedophiles are married men, Greely refuses to 
blame celibacy for sexual abuse by priests.

      "Sex and the church" by Kenneth Woodward. Newsweek, Aug 16, 
1993.  Pages 38-45.  Topic: CATHOLICS.  See also 8840, 8610, and 8330.

title: SHOULD WE CLONE HUMANS?
words:
"Human cloning is not just another technological step to be 
judged in terms of its effects on those cloned. What [it] would do to 
all of us [raises] intertwined theological questions of the first 
magnitude."

   A significant ethical debate was touched off last fall when a 
doctor at the George Washington University Medical Center succeeded 
in cloning human embryos.

   Some commentators, viewing the issue strictly as a matter of the 
autonomy of the individual, argue that society has no right to invade 
the privacy of those who produce (and therefore own) the embryos.  
Others who emphasize how cloning can help childless couples see this 
technology (along with any other that solves the problem of 
infertility) as morally acceptable.  Both of these approaches are 
extremely short-sighted because cloning humans is not merely a 
private matter; it is a three-dimensional question of social ethics.

   Wholeness.  The notion of eugenics, the preferential breeding of 
genetically superior individuals, has gained a surprising amount of 
public acceptance in our culture, as seen in offhanded references to 
"the right to a healthy child," which necessitates a corresponding 
right to reject the imperfect.  We now have the medical capability of 
diagnosing genetic defects prior to birth, and the courts have ruled 
on a number of "wrongful life" suits in which the child alleges the 
parents committed a crime by allowing him or her to be born.  A 
multitude of problems arise out of the practice of eugenics (What 
defects are unacceptable?  What attributes are most desirable? Who 
decides?), but the major concern is the way it perverts 
attitudes--society begins to value an individual only in terms of the 
specific characteristic he or she was genetically engineered to have.

   Uniqueness.  Human diversity (racial, cultural, sexual) is a 
quintessential aspect of our having been created in the image of 
God.  We must resist any development that collapses the individual 
into a mere collection of genetic data.

   Sanctity of life.  Pre-embryos are alive, and they are human.  
Given the proper circumstances, each fertilized ovum has the 
potential to move through the developmental stages of becoming a 
person.  If we begin regarding pre-embryos as nonpersons, how long 
will it be until the same attitude is extended to embryos?  It will 
only further erode our corporate respect for nascent human life.  
"Progress" in medical technology has a tendency to be irreversible; 
it is almost impossible to backtrack even when abuses become apparent 
further down the road.

   We need uniform national controls to ensure that the pre-embryo is 
treated as a person.

      "Should we clone humans?" by Richard McCormick.  Christian 
Century, Nov 17, 1993. Pages 1148-1149.  Topic: CLONING.  See also 
9000, 8223, and 7893.

title: SALVAGING AMERICA'S CULTURE OF DEATH
words:
"Death of culture is a necessary product and parallel to the 
culture of death."

   If Christians are going to influence America's "culture of death," 
says Southern Baptist Seminary president Albert Mohler, we "must 
recover our own moral authority."  That can happen only when we are 
living in submission to the Lord's authority, he says.  The church's 
mandate is to "let the light shine in the darkness."

   The church is a "cognitive minority," in a culture of darkness 
where abortion, violence, homosexuality, the increasing acceptance of 
divorce, and a general revolt against authority prevail.  The church 
must be a "culture of life," defending life at every level, from the 
womb to the nursing home.  We are to bear witness to the truth of 
God's wrath against sin and of His glorious grace in redemption.  We 
are to live in hope because of our confidence in the One in whom our 
hope is placed.

   The 20th century has been one of increasing death, Mohler says, 
citing as evidence the two world wars, the concentration camps, and 
the atomic bomb.  Now RU486 is on the horizon, and bills to prevent 
late-term abortion are stalled in Congress.  The uncertainty of the 
future produces anxiety in our culture.  The church of Jesus Christ 
must begin to "pass the light from candle to candle."

 "Salvaging America's culture of death" by David Porter.  SBC Life, 
May 1997.  Page 13.  Topic: CULTURE, AMERICAN.  See also 12283, 
12177, and 12017.

title: SOCIAL ILLS GROWING
words:
The quality of American life has dropped steadily over the past 
20 years, according to a recent sociological study.  Marc L. 
Miringoff's"Index of Social Health," which tracks 17 social problems, 
has plunged 51 percent since its inception in 1970.
    Five problems are at their worst ever: teen suicide, child abuse, 
the growing gap between the rich and the poor, the number of people 
without health insurance, and the money people over 65 must spend on 
healthcare.

title: SHOW THAT YOU CARE
words:
Rabbi Harold Kushner, speaking to Richmond Academy of Medicine 
(9/10/92):

   "Show that you care. Caring helps people heal. You are called upon 
not only to dispense wisdom and prescriptions, but also to dispense 
love and caring and trust.

   "Very sick people are not afraid of dying. They're afraid of pain 
and abandonment."

   He cited a study that examined how long a person could keep a bare 
foot in a bucket of ice water.  The results showed that the foot 
stayed in twice as long when someone else was in the room. "Another 
person can double the amount of pain we can endure," he said.

  "People in pain need so little from us.  But they need that little 
so much.

  "Everything that's done need not be extraordinary.  When you can't 
fix a situation, just sit down and help the other person cry."

title: SOME THINGS THAT DO PREDICT HAPPINESS
words:
Psychology Today, 1993.    Research has uncovered some things 
that do predict people's happiness and satisfaction with life:
     -aerobically fit and healthy bodies
     -realistic goals and expectations
     -supportive friendships
     -an tintimate, sexually warm, marriage
     -a faith that provides support, purpose and acceptance
     -The best definition I know is that happiness is a sense of 
well-being, a feeling that life as a whole is going well.  That comes 
from two sources--how happy people feel and to what extent they find 
their life satisfying.
      Happiness doesn't depend on how old you are or how much money 
you make, whether you're male or female, or what race you belong to.  
It does depend on certain personality traits, whether you have close 
relationships and an active religious faith.

title: SOMETHING TO REMIND US
words:
There are times when all of us try to put ourselves in God's seat.  
There are times when all of us act as if the world is our fiefdom and 
we are supreme over all we survey.  We forget that everything we have 
is on loan to us from God.  We are only temporary tenants.
   There was a church located next door to a supermarket.  Since the 
church was short on parking spaces and the supermarket was closed on 
Sundays, the church leaders asked the owner of the supermarket for 
persmission to park in his lot. The owner's response was, "Fine.  You 
are welcome to use it 51 weeks a year."  "What about the other week?" 
the church members asked.  "That week," said the owner of the market, 
"I'll chain off the lot so you will always remember that the lot 
belongs to me and not the church."
    That's what God did in the Ten Commandments.

title: SMALL BUT POWERFUL
words:
Charles Steinmetz was a dwarf, ugly and deformed, but he had one 
of the greatest minds in the field of electricity that the world has 
ever known.  Steinmetz built the great generators for Henry Ford in 
his first plant in Dearborn, Michigan.
   One day those generators broke down, and the plant came to a 
halt.  They brought in ordinary mechanics and helpers who couldn't 
get the generators going again.  They were losing money. Then Ford 
called Steinmetz.  The genuius came, seemed to putter around for a 
few hours, and then threw the switch that put the great Ford plant 
back into operation.  A few days later, Henry Ford received a bill 
from Steinmetz fro $10,000.
   Although Ford was a very rich man, he returned the bill with a 
note, "Charlie, isn't this bill just a little high for a few hours of 
tinkering around on those motors?"  Steinmetz returned the bill to 
Ford.  This time it read: "For tinkering around on the motors:, $10.  
For knowing where to tinker: $9,990.  Total: $10,000.  Henry Ford 
paid the bill.

title: STARVES 10-MONTH OLD
words:
Washington D.C. - 5/95
 While 10-month-old Thomas Owensby lay dying of malnutrition, 
prosecutors say, his mother was buying new clothes and going to night 
clubs, and his grandmother was smoking crack cocaine.
 The two women--Sandra Owensby, 24, and her mother, Constance Rice, 
42--pleaded guilty yesterday in Superior Court for their roles in 
what officials called the starvation homicide of the child.
 U.S. Attorney ERic Holder said young Thomas weighed only 11 pounds, 
was severely under-developed and had a distended abdomen when he was 
found dead on the kitchen table in the women's home on April 2, 
1993.  Both women had the financial means to care for Thomas.

title: SO EXCITING!
words:
Lauren Collier, my 12-year-old grandaughter, her sister and I were 
breaking a pony together. We had tamed it to where it would lead 
fairly comfortably.  Then we started "backing" the horse to get it 
used to weight on its back.  After some tense time, it began to 
settle down.
   Later we felt the pony was ready for someone to get on its back.  
I put Lauren up there.  The pony tensed up but with reassurances and 
stroking settled back down.  Lauren sat on his back, just thrilled at 
what she was doing and said, "This is so exciting I just feel like 
singing."
   Music helps us say things from the heart better than any other way.

title: SUFFERING PRODUCES PERSEVERANCE

character,
hope. (Romans 5:3b-4, NIV)

On December 29, 1987, a Soviet cosmonaut returned to the Earth after 
326 days
in orbit. He was in good health, which hadn't always been the case in 
those
record-breaking voyages.

Five years earlier, touching down after 211 days in space, two 
cosmonauts
suffered from dizziness, high pulse rates and heart palpitations. They
couldn't walk for a week. After 30 days, they were still undergoing 
therapy
for atrophied muscles and weakened hearts.

At zero gravity, the muscles of the body begin to waste away because 
there is
no resistance.

To counteract this, the Soviets prescribed a vigorous exercise 
program for the
cosmonauts. They invented the "penguin suit," a running suit laced 
with
elastic bands. It resists every move the cosmonauts make, forcing 
them to
exert their strength. Apparently the regimen is helping.

We often long dreamily for days without difficulty, but God knows 
better. The
easier our lives, the weaker our spiritual fiber, for strength of any 
kind
grows only by exertion.

Personal Challenge:
In the difficulties you face this week, tackle them with a sense of 
God's
purpose. Thank God for the good He wants to accomplish in you.

to plants?  
      "Sweetheart, let's make up.  Have this deceased squirrel."

      If airline seat cushions are such great flotation devices, why 
don't you ever see anyone take one to the beach?


 
      Can't we just get rid of wine lists?  Do we really have to be 
reminded every time we go out to a nice restaurant that we have no 
idea what we are doing? Why don't they just give us a trigonometry 
quiz with the menu?

      All the king's HORSES and all the king's men?  Are you kidding 
me? No wonder they couldn't put Humpty together again.  Just what did 
those idiots expect the horses to do, anyway? 

       Isn't it weird that we drink milk, stuff designed to nourish 
baby cows? How did THAT happen?  Did some cattleman once say, "Oh, 
man, I can't wait till them calves are done so I can get ME a hit of 
that stuff."


      
       What's with this weird hotel custom of leaving a piece of 
chocolate on the pillow?  I awoke thinking my brain had hemorrhaged 
some sort of fecal matter.


       
        Did you ever notice, when you are sitting at a red light, 
that when the person in front of you pulls up a couple of inches, you 
are compelled to move up too?
Do we really think we are making progress toward our destination?  
         "Whew, I thought we would be late, but now that I am nine 
inches closer, I can stop for coffee and a danish!"

told him. With that, the intern took his last remaining blank piece 
of paper, put it on the photocopier and proceeded to make five blank 
copies.



I was in a car dealership a while ago when a large motor home was 
towed into the garage.  The front of the vehicle was in dire need of 
repair and the whole thing generally looked like an extra in 
"Twister."

I asked the manager what had happened.  He told me that the driver 
had set the cruise control, then went in the back to make a sandwich.

title: SERVICE WITHOUT PRAISE
words:
Gloria Spann was Jimmy Carter's sister. A number of years ago, while 
Jimmy Carter was still president, Spann gave an interview to the 
Boston Globe, in which she spoke movingly of their father: 

          You know the man in the novel "Magnificent Obsession" who 
did things for people provided they would never tell anybody he had 
done it? My father lived like that.

          One of the families in town was just destitute one 
Christmas. The town got up a basket. He ordered a silk dress sent to 
(the mother of the family) anonymously. I said, "Daddy, why did you 
do that?" He said, "She has no money, but she's getting food--she's 
being looked after. But never in her life has she had a silk dress."

title: SOME CASUAL OBSERVATIONS ABOUT LIFE
words:

title: SIMPLE RULES FOR DATING MY DAUGHTER
words:

Rule One:
If you pull into my driveway and honk you'd better be delivering a
package, because you're sure not picking anything else up.

Rule Two:
You do not touch my daughter in front of me. You may glance at her, so
long as you do not peer at anything below her neck. If you cannot 
keep your
eyes or hands off of my daughter's body, I will remove them.


come off during the course of your date with my daughter, I will take



"barrier method" of some kind can kill you.  Let me elaborate, when it



In order for us to get to know each other, we should talk about 
sports,
politics, and other issues of the day. Please do not do this.  The 
only
information I require from you is an indication of when you expect to
have my daughter safely back at my house, and the only word I need 
from
you on this subject is "early."

Rule Six:
I have no doubt you are a popular fellow, with many opportunities to
date other girls. This is fine with me as long as it is okay with my
daughter. Otherwise, once you have gone out with my little girl, you 
will continue
to date no one but her until she is finished with you. If you make her
cry, I will make you cry.

Rule Seven:
As you stand in my front hallway, waiting for my daughter to appear, 
and
more than an hour goes by, do not sigh and fidget.  If you want to be 
on
time for the movie, you should not be dating. My daughter is putting 
on
her makeup, a process that can take longer than painting the Golden 
Gate
Bridge. Instead of just standing there, why don't you do something
useful, like changing the oil in my car?

Rule Eight:
The following places are not appropriate for a date with my daughter:
Places where there are beds, sofas, or anything softer than a wooden
stool. Places where there are no parents, policemen, or nuns within
eyesight. Places where there is darkness. Places where there is 
dancing,
holding hands, or happiness. Places where the ambient temperature is
warm enough to induce my daughter to wear shorts, tank tops, midriff
T-shirts, or anything other than overalls, a sweater, and a goose 
down parka
zipped up to her throat. Movies with a strong romantic or sexual 
theme are to
be avoided; movies which features chain saws are okay. Hockey games 
are
okay. Old folks homes are better.

Rule Nine:
Do not lie to me. I may appear to be a potbellied, balding, 
middle-aged,
dimwitted has-been. But on issues relating to my daughter, I am the
all-knowing, merciless potentate of your universe. If I ask you where
you are going and with whom, you have one chance to tell me the 
truth, the whole
truth and nothing but the truth. I have a shotgun, a shovel, and five
acres behind the house. Do not trifle with me.

Rule Ten:
Be afraid. Be very afraid. It takes very little for me to mistake the
sound of your car in the driveway for a chopper coming in over a rice
paddy outside of Hanoi. When my Agent Orange starts acting up, the
voices in my head frequently tell me to clean the guns as I wait for 
you to
bring my daughter home. As soon as you pull into the driveway, you
should exit your car with both hands in plain sight. Speak the 
perimeter
password, announce in a clear voice that you have brought my daughter
home safely and early, then return to your car--there is no need for 
you
to come inside. The camouflaged face at the window is mine.

title: STUPID CRIMINALS
words:
Drug Possession Defendant Christopher Jansen, on trial in March in
Pontiac, Michigan, said he had been searched without a warrant. The 
prosecutor said the officer didn't need a warrant because a "bulge" 
in Christopher's jacket could have been a gun.  Nonsense, said 
Christopher, who happened to be wearing the same jacket that day in 
court.  He handed it over so the judge could see it.  The judge 
discovered a packet of cocaine in the pocket and
laughed so hard he required a five-minute recess to compose himself.

Oklahoma City-Dennis Newton was on trial for the armed robbery of a 
convenience store in a district court when he fired his lawyer. 
Assistant district attorney Larry Jones said Newton, 47, was doing a 
fair job of defending himself until the store manager testified that 
Newton was the robber.  Newton jumped up, accused the woman of lying, 
and then said, "I should have blown your head off." The defendant 
paused, then quickly added, "if I'd been the one that was  there."  
The jury took 20 minutes to
convict Newton and recommended a 30-year sentence.

R.C. Gaitlan, 21 walked up to two patrol officers who were showing 
their squad car computer equipment to children in a Detroit 
neighborhood.When he asked how the system worked, the officer asked 
him for identification. Gaitlan gave them his drivers license, they 
entered it into the computer, and moments later they arrested Gaitlan 
because information on the screen showed Gaitlan was wanted for a two 
year old armed robbery in St. Louis, Missouri.

title: SKEPTICISM OF THE MIRACULOUS
words:

Nine-year-old Danny came bursting out of Sunday school like a wild 
stallion. His eyes were darting in every direction as he tried to 
locate either mom or dad. Finally, after a quick search, he grabbed 
his Daddy by the leg and yelled, "Man, that story of Moses and all 
those people crossing the Red Sea was great!" His father looked 
down, smiled, and asked the boy to tell him about it.

"Well, the Israelites got out of Egypt, but Pharaoh and his army 
chased after them. So the Jews ran as fast as they could until they 
got to the Red Sea. The Egyptian Army was gettin' closer and 
closer. So Moses got on his walkie-talkie and told the Israeli Air 
Force to bomb the Egyptians. While that was happening, the Israeli 
Navy built a pontoon bridge so the people could cross over. They 
made it!

By now old dad was shocked. "Is THAT the way they taught you the 
story?"

Well, no, not exactly," Danny admitted, "but if I told you the way 
they told it to us, you'd never believe it."

title: SMELL OF BAKED BREAD MAY BE BAD
words:
A recent Cincinnati Enquirer headline read,
  "Smell of baked bread may be health hazard."

  The article went on to describe the dangers of the smell of baking
  bread. The main danger,  apparently, is that the organic components 
of
  this aroma may break down ozone (I'm not making this stuff up).

  I was horrified. When are we going to do something about bread-
  induced global warming?  Sure, we attack tobacco companies, but 
when is
  the government going to go after Big Bread?

  Well, I've done a little research, and what I've discovered should
  make anyone think twice....

  1: More than 98 percent of convicted felons are bread eaters.

  2: Fully HALF of all children who grow up in bread-consuming 
households
      score below average on standardized tests.

  3: In the 18th century, when virtually all bread was baked in the
     home, the average life  expectancy was less than 50 years; infant
     mortality rates were unacceptably high; many women died in 
childbirth;
     and diseases such as typhoid, yellow fever and influenza ravaged 
whole
     nations.

  4: More than 90 percent of violent crimes are committed within 24
      hours of eating bread.

  5: Bread is made from a substance called "dough." It has been proven
      that as little as one pound of dough can be used to suffocate a
      mouse.
     The average American eats more bread than that in one month!

  6: Primitive tribal societies that have no bread exhibit a low
      occurrence of cancer, Alzheimer's, Parkinson's disease and
      osteoporosis.

  7: Bread has been proven to be addictive. Subjects deprived of bread
     and given only water to eat begged for bread after only two days.

  8: Bread is often a "gateway" food item, leading the user to 
"harder"
      items such as butter, jelly, peanut butter and even cold cuts.

  9: Bread has been proven to absorb water. Since the human body is 
more
      than 90 percent water, it follows that eating bread could lead 
to
      your body being taken over by this absorptive food product, 
turning you
      into a soggy, gooey bread-pudding person.

  10: New-born babies can choke on bread.

  11: Bread is baked at temperatures as high as 400 degrees 
Fahrenheit!
       That kind of heat can kill an adult in less than one minute.

  12: Most American bread eaters are utterly unable to distinguish 
between
       significant scientific fact and meaningless statistical 
babbling.

   In light of these frightening statistics, we propose the following 
bread
   restrictions:

  1: No advertising of bread within 1000 feet of a school.

  2: A 300 percent federal tax on all bread to pay for all the 
societal
     ills we might associate with bread.

  3: No animal or human images, nor any primary colours (which may

title: SALVATION IS A GROWING EXPERIENCE
words:
You may rememeber comedian Yakov Smirnoff. He said when
he first came to the United States from Russia, he wasn't
prepared for the incredible variety of instant products
available in American grocery stores. He says, "On my first
shopping trip, I saw powdered milk--you just add water, and you
get milk. Then I saw powdered orange juice--you just add water,
and you get orange juice. And then I saw baby powder, and I
thought to my self, What a country!"

One of the most basic assumptions made about life change is that
it happens instantly at salvation. According to this belief,
when someone gives his  or her life to Christ, there is an
immediate, substantive, in-depth, miraculous change in habits,
attitudes, and character. As a result disciples are born not
made.

. . .The question for rethinking discipleship is this: Are these
assumptions valid? If they are, then working this formula in the
life of the church should consistently give the same result: a
new community of people who are becoming increasingly like Jesus
in their life and thought. If that is not the answer a church
gets when it wroks the equation, then it needs to rethink
whether the formula is sound.

Unfortunately, many churches are not getting the correct answer.
In fact, a Search Institute study has found that only 11 percent
of churchgoing teenagers have a well-developed faith, rising to
only 32 percent for churchgoing adults. Why? Because true life
change only begins at salvation, takes more than just time, is
about trainig not trying, and is a team effort.

James Enery White, Rethinking the Chruch, Baker, 1997, p. 55-57.

title: SOME DECISIONS ARE PYRRHIC VICTORIES
words:
Pyrrhus (pir'_s). 319-272 b.c..
 King of Epirus (306-302 and 297-272) who 
    defeated the Romans at Heraclea (280) and 
    Asculum (279) despite his own staggering 
    losses.

Around 280 B.C., the King of Epirus (which is now part of Greece) 
invaded what is now southern Italy to attack the Romans.  He fancied 
himself as the next Alexander the Great.  He met and defeated the 
Romans at Asculum, but sustained heavy casualties in doing so.  
Afterward, he exclaimed, "One more such victory, and I am lost."

The Romans later defeated his spent army and pushed it off the 
Italian peninsula.  He then returned to homeland, was defeated in a 
battle for local control and ultimately was killed by a street mob.  
Eventually the Romans conquered his weakened country.  The result of 
King Pyrrhus' costly war against Rome was the destruction of Epirus.
topics:
DECISIONS
CHOICES
WISDOM
PYRRHIC VICTORIES
WAR
ROMANS
VICTORY

title: SIMEON WAS NOT A PRIEST
words:
I have an embarrassing confession to make. I realized only a few
> days ago what Luke is trying to do in this text. For years I had
> read it and made the unwarranted assumption that old Simeon was a
> priest. Anna is described as a prophetess so I assumed Simeon a
> priest--good balance and symmetry. But something about the text
> kept nagging me. And then I realized what it was. Simeon was not a
> priest at all. He was a simple old man--a layman--an ordinary
> person. And Anna was not an official prophetess. She was merely a
> devout old woman who came to the temple a lot. Luke was only
> underlining a point he had begun to make by telling about the
> shepherds who were called from their fields and flocks to worship
> Christ: The coming of Christ was to simple folk! Luke, did you
> notice, doesn't even tell the story of the wise men; that's
> Matthew. Luke's whole concern, in the stories surrounding the birth
> of Jesus, is to emphasize one thing: Christianity is based on the
> faith of simple folk.
>
> Come to think of it, that's what Luke's whole Gospel is about. It's
> what the book of Acts is about. Luke wrote the book of Acts. It
> wasn't the priest and Pharisees who received the Kingdom of God, it
> was the laypeople, the untutored, the untrained, the
> unsophisticated. It was simple fisher men like James and John and
> Peter. It was unimportant public officials like Matthew. It was
> women like Mary and Martha and Mary Magdalene.
>
> Christianity my friends, has never been a religion of Priest and
> theologians, minister's and teachers; from the very beginning it
> has been a religion of devout men and women with no claim
> whatsoever to professional expertise about their faith. This is
> important to remember.
>
> God never intended the church to be an organization of ministers.
> What he did intend it to be is an organization of laypersons,
> all "righteous and devout" like old Simeon, all devoted to fasting
> and prayer like old Anna, and all ready, in simple faith, to
> receive his Kingdom and rejoice in it. Ministers, in Christianity,
> are expendable; good, simple folk are not!
>

title: SPECIAL COMPUTER TERMS
words:
Broadband

A type of data transmission in which a single medium (wire) can carry
several channels at once. Cable TV, for example, uses broadband
transmission. In contrast, baseband transmission allows only one 
signal
at a
time.


Microfiber

A technology that uses glass (or plastic) threads (fibers) to transmit
data.
A fiber optic cable consists of a bundle of glass threads, each of 
which
is
capable of transmitting messages modulated onto light waves.

Fiber optics has several advantages over traditional metal 
communications
lines:

       Fiber optic cables have a much greater bandwidth than metal
cables. This
means that they can carry more data.

       Fiber optic cables are less susceptible than metal cables to
interference.

       Fiber optic cables are much thinner and lighter than metal
wires.

       Data can be transmitted digitally (the natural form for 
computer
data)
rather than analogically.

The main disadvantage of fiber optics is that the cables are 
expensive to
install. In addition, they are more fragile than wire and are 
difficult
to
split.

Fiber optics is a particularly popular technology for local-area
networks.
In addition, telephone companies are steadily replacing traditional
telephone lines with fiber optic cables. In the future, almost all
communications will employ fiber optics.


Bandwidth

The amount of data that can be transmitted in a fixed amount of time. 
For
digital devices, the bandwidth is usually expressed in bits per
second(bps)
or bytes per second. For analog devices, the bandwidth is expressed in
cycles per second, or Hertz (Hz).

The bandwidth is particularly important for I/O devices. For example, 
a
fast
disk drive can be hampered by a bus with a low bandwidth. This is the
main
reason that new buses, such as AGP,  have been developed for the PC.


IP

Abbreviation of Internet Protocol, pronounced as two separate 
letters. IP
specifies the format of packets, also called datagrams, and the
addressing
scheme. Most networks combine IP with a higher-level protocol called
Transport Control Protocol (TCP), which establishes a virtual 
connection
between a destination and a source.
IP by itself is something like the postal system. It allows you to
address a
package and drop it in the system, but there's no direct link between 
you
and the recipient. TCP/IP, on the other hand, establishes a connection
between two hosts so that they can send messages back and forth for a
period
of time.

The current version of IP is IPv4. A new version, called IPv6 or 
IPng, is
under development.

Switches

 (1) In networks, a device that filters and forwards packets between 
LAN
segments. Switches operate at the data link layer (layer 2) of the OSI
Reference Model and therefore support any packet protocol. LANs that 
use
switches to join segments are called switched LANs or, in the case of
Ethernet networks, switched Ethernet LANs.
(2) A small lever or button. The switches on the back of printers and 
on
expansion boards are called DIP switches. A switch that has just two
positions is called a toggle switch.
(3) Another word for option or parameter -- a symbol that you add to a
command to modify the command's behavior.


Ring network

A local-area network (LAN) whose topology is a ring. That is, all of 
the
nodes are connected in a closed loop. Messages travel around the ring,
with
each node reading those messages addressed to it. One of the 
advantages
of
ring networks is that they can span larger distances than other types 
of
networks, such as bus networks, because each node regenerates 
messages as
they pass through it.


Scalable

(1) A popular buzzword that refers to how well a hardware or software
system
can adapt to increased demands. For example, a scalable network system
would
be one that can start with just a few nodes but can easily expand to
thousands of nodes. Scalability can be a very important feature 
because
it
means that you can invest in a system with confidence you won't 
outgrow
it.
(2) Refers to anything whose size can be changed. For example, a font 
is
said to be scalable if it can be represented in different sizes.


Server

A computer or device on a network that manages network resources. For
example, a file server is a computer and storage device dedicated to
storing
files. Any user on the network can store files on the server. A print
server
is a computer that manages one or more printers, and a network server 
is
a
computer that manages network traffic. A database server is a computer
system that processes database queries.

Servers are often dedicated, meaning that they perform no other tasks
besides their server tasks. On multiprocessing operating systems,
however, a
single computer can execute several programs at once. A server in this
case
could refer to the program that is managing resources rather than the
entire
computer.


Application

A program or group of programs designed for end users. Software can be
divided into two general classes: systems software and applications
software. Systems software consists of low-level programs that 
interact
with
the computer at a very basic level. This includes operating systems,
compilers, and utilities for managing computer resources.

In contrast, applications software (also called end-user programs)
includes
database programs, word processors, and spreadsheets. Figuratively
speaking,
applications software sits on top of systems software because it is
unable
to run without the operating system and system utilities.

  SYDNEY (Reuters) - A swarm of bees attacked a mother and her baby in



kept in



door and died,

found


  "I have never seen a bee attack as bad as this before," Dr Alyson 
Kakakios,

title: SOME SEINFELD-ISMS

 animals allowed except for Seeing Eye Dogs?" Who is that sign for? 

 Why do people give each other flowers? To celebrate various 

squirrel."

 Can't we just get rid of wine lists? Do we really have to be

with
 the menu?
 

 
 Isn't it weird that we drink milk, stuff designed to nourish baby

 stuff."
 

 When you see an ad for a suit, do they say, "And look at the zipper! 
 Carefully hidden, but easily accessible when you need it!" I think

title: SALT CAN BE HURTFUL AND HELPFUL
words:
SALT

Sodium is an extremely active element found naturally only in 
combined form; it always links itself to another element. Chlorine, 
on the other hand, is the poisonous gas that gives bleach its 
offensive odor. When sodium and chlorine are combined, the result is 
sodium chloride--common table salt--the substance we use to preserve 
meat and bring out its flavor. Love and truth can be like sodium and 
chlorine. Love without truth is flighty, sometimes blind, willing to 
combine with various doctrines. On the other hand, truth by itself 
can be offensive, sometimes even poisonous. Spoken without love, it 
can turn people away from the gospel. When truth and love are 
combined in an individual or a church, however, then we have what 
Jesus called "the salt of the earth," and we're able to preserve and 
bring out the beauty of our faith.



horse that could

taking a
  cautious approach in trying to determine if the skull, found in a 
cloth sack in a
  wooded area near Tralee, County Kerry, belong to the horse believed 
to have
  been kidnapped by the Irish Republican Army in 1983, according to 
the Reuters
  news service.

  Winner of the English Derby and Irish Derby, Shergar retired in 
1981 with

title: SYMPTOMS OF SEVERE MENTAL ILLNESS
words:
Symptoms of Severe
Mental Illnesses

DEPRESSION
What is depression? Depression isn't just a passing funk that lifts 
in a few days. People who have depression experience at least five of 
the following symptoms, which must include the first or second nearly 
every day, all day, for at least two weeks:

	Persistent feelings of sadness or emptiness
	Loss of interest or pleasure in activities or hobbies that were once 
enjoyed, including sex
	Feelings of helplessness, guilt and worthlessness
	Insomnia, early-morning awakening, or oversleeping
	Change in appetite
	Decreased energy, fatigue, and feeling slowed down
	Restlessness and irritability
	Difficulty concentrating and remembering
	Thoughts of suicide or suicide attempts
	Persistent physical symptoms that do not respond to medical treatment

BIPOLAR DISORDER
Bipolar disorder (manic-depressive disorder) is a condition in which 
an individual experiences severe lows (depressive) alternating with 
extreme, inappropriate highs (mania).

A MANIC EPISODE IS characterized by a distinct period of mood change 
that is either elevated (to the point of elation), expansive, or 
irritable. During this phase, which may last from several days t~ a 
few months, the patient's behavior causes difficulties in both 
professional and social activities. Symptoms of a manic phase may 
include:

	Decreased need for sleep
	Increased pressure of speech
	Distractibility and/or irritability
	Excessive involvement in activities that have a high risk for pain 
consequences that are not recognized
	Inflated self-esteem or grandiosity

The patient may become psychotic with delusions and hallucinations. 
Frequently, those experiencing a manic episode do not realize they 
are affected and will therefore resist any medical treatment attempt. 
Close friends will recognize the mood and behavior patterns as being 
excessive, while the casual observer may not see anything disturbing.

A DEPRESSIVE EPISODE usually lasts two weeks to many months, during 
which time the patient will experience a lack of interest or pleasure 
in all activities. Patients may describe themselves as feeling sad or 
blue, devoid of motivation or worth. These feelings and thoughts may 
or
may not be stated openly in front of others. Symptoms of a depressive 
phase may include:

	Sleep disturbance (sleeping more or less than usual)
	Change in appetite
	Feeling sad, worthless, or guilty without cause
	Concentration difficulties
	Thoughts of death and/or suicide attempts

The course of a depressive episode may vary from person to person. 
Symptoms may develop over a period of days or weeks, or they may 
occur suddenly, without warning. Sudden onset of this condition can 
be caused by external factors, including stress, death of a family 
member, or divorce. Duration of an episode will vary and depends on 
the medical treatment employed.

SCHIZOPHRENIA
Schizophrenia is a serious brain disorder. It is a disease that makes 
it difficult for a person to tell the difference between real and 
unreal experiences, to think logically, and to have normal emotional 
responses to others and to behave normally in social situations. 
People with schizophrenia may have difficulty in remembering, talking 
and behaving appropriately.
Schizophrenia is not a split personality. It is also not caused by 
bad upbringing, personal weakness or laziness. Schizophrenia is a 
disease with a physical cause, like cancer or heart disease.

POSITIVE SYMPTOMS OF SCHIZOPHRENIA

	Disordered Thinking: Thoughts jump between completely unrelated 
topics or may be blocked. The person may talk nonsense, make up 
words or replace words with sounds and rhymes.
	Delusions: False beliefs or thoughts with no basis in reality. For 
example, someone from the house next door is trying to control the 
patient's thoughts or feelings.
	Hallucinations: Hearing, seeing or feeling things that are not 
there. People with schizophrenia may hear voices that comment on 
their behavior or give them commands.

NEGATIVE SYMPTOMS OF SCHIZOPHRENIA

	Blunted (or flat) affect: Lacking awareness of other people's 
feelings. The person does not show emotions on the face, avoids eye 
contact and makes few gestures or movements. He or she does not 
respond with normal conversation when spoken to. In severe cases, the 
person may become nearly motionless (catatonia).
	Avolition: Lacking energy, spontaneity and initiative.
	Anhedonia: Lacking pleasure or interest in activities that were once 
enjoyable.
	Attention deficit: Difficulty in concentrating.

title: SCHOOLBOY GETS 15 YEARS FOR KILLING MOTHER
words:
Updated 8:03 AM ET May 2, 2000

  BEIJING (Reuters) - A 17-year-old boy who killed his mother during 
a quarrel
  over school work has been jailed for 15 years in a case that 
shocked China and
  sparked debate over the high pressures of the exam system, media 
reports said
  on Tuesday.

  The boy, Xu Li, smashed his mother's head with a hammer in a fit of 
rage.

  He snapped under her constant nagging to score in the top 10 of his 
class in
  twice-yearly examinations, a task he felt was impossible, newspaper 
reports said.

  The mother was also under stress. A poor woman whose husband lived 
away
  from home, she scrimped and saved to bring up the boy and pay his 
school fees,
  supplementing her day job by sewing.

  The court in China's eastern province of Zhejiang convicted the boy 
of homicide,
  newspapers said.

  The judge, however, applied a relatively light jail sentence by 
Chinese standards,
  citing the boy's age.

  Murderers are often executed in China.

  The brutality of the killing has horrified ordinary Chinese but the 
case has also
  reignited controversy over an education system heavily geared 
toward passing
  exams, which begin during the quest for a kindergarten place.

  Pressure-cooker exam systems are common around Asia, and in Japan
  contribute to a high incidence of suicide among high school 
students.

  But China's one-child family policy puts an even heavier burden on 
children to
  excel at school, since they carry all their parents' hopes for a 
coveted university
  place.

  Parents commonly pack children off to boarding school at age three 
or four to
  ensure maximum exposure to classroom learning and a better shot at 
joining a
  fast-track education system aimed at getting middle school 
graduates into
  colleges.

  Critics say the system encourages rote learning, discourages 
creative thinking and
  robs millions of Chinese of a carefree childhood.

title: SEVEN WAYS TO MAKE AND LOSE MONEY IN THE STOCK MARKET
words:
As Time Goes By, The 
Fundamentals Always Apply
                                                                  By 
H. Bradlee Perry
                                           Former Chairman, David L. 
Babson & Co.

Editor's Note: The following column contains a number of important 
points on successful long-term investing which Brad Perry and the 
Babson Staff Letter have emphasized over the years. We think many of 
our readers will agree that in today's exuberant, highly volatile
stock market, they are points that are well worth repeating. 
(Reprinted with permission from H. Bradlee Perry)

Anyone can make money in stocks. All it takes is common sense and a 
dedication to learning the lessons of investment history, analyzing 
the approaches that have proven to be rewarding and those that have 
failed.

People tend to make investing much more complicated than it should 
be. So they tend to reject common-sense strategies because they look 
too simple. But those, by far, are what work best.


                                                  Seven Ways to Make 
Money In Stocks

1.	Invest in good businesses with superior growth and profitability.

Some businesses have much more favorable fundamental characteristics
than others. For example, the market for prescription drugs is 
growing rapidly in all parts of the world and isn't subject to 
declines during economic recessions. The business is dominated by a 
few large companies that compete aggressively in research and 
development, but not with price cutting and other competitive 
excesses. And the profit margins in pharmaceuticals are high. That is 
why this industry has been one of the most rewarding for investors in 
the past 50 years.

In contrast, demand for automobiles is growing very slowly in all 
advanced countries. Sales of cars fluctuate widely, depending on 
economic conditions and the level of interest rates. Competition is 
intense among over a dozen major companies headquartered in various 
parts of the world. Earnings have a roller coaster pattern and the 
average level of profit margins is low.

These differences explain why the earnings per share (EPS) of leading 
drug companies have multiplied 45 times in the past 35 years and 
their stocks have risen over 80 times, whereas profits of the three 
U.S. car makers have grown just five times in the same period and 
their share prices have advanced a mere five times.

Would you rather have an investment of $10,000 grow over 35 years to 
$800,000 or $50,000?

2.	Focus on high-quality companies, particularly those with strong 
competitive positions.

History shows that in at least nine cases out of ten, today's leader 
in any established business (that is one beyond the startup phase, 
when early leaders do falter) will be tomorrow's leader, and today's 
laggard will be tomorrow's laggard.

3. Concentrate on the long term.

One of the few things we know for certain about the stock market is 
that in the long term, it rises in close parallel with the growth of 
corporate earnings and dividends. The same is true of prices of 
individual stocks. Moreover, the basic characteristics of different 
types of industries change very little over long periods of time. The 
good industries stay good and the bad industries stay bad.

No one knows exactly what the earnings of Cisco and Lucent will be 
next year, or even the next quarter. But we do know that these are 
two of the strongest companies in an industry that has had, and will 
continue to have, a favorable long-term growth trend.

Basing one's decision on such facts will be a lot more profitable 
than trying to guess the short-term swings in those companies' 
quarterly earnings and stock prices, and buying their shares on the 
basis of those guesses.

4.	Be willing to go against the consensus.

Something else we know for certain about the stock market is that it 
fluctuates, at times very sharply in reflection of changing investor 
moods.

When people are unhappy with a good company because it has just 
provided some sort of disappointment, those who have the courage of 
their convictions about the company's long-term prospects will make a 
great purchase. This was certainly true of those who bought 
Hewlett-Packard at the end of October
 it's risen 55 percent since then.

When bank stocks were in the doghouse with investors during the 
summer of 1990 at the peak of worry about huge
losses on real estate loans, the shares of NationsBank (now Bank of 
America) dropped 70 percent and most people were scared of the stock. 
Those who had the courage and foresight to buy NationsBank then have 
multiplied their capital six and a half times.

5.	Pay close attention to valuation.

History shows that even the best companies can become overvalued and 
be poor investments for a long time, despite continued good growth in 
earnings and dividends.

A classic example is Coca-Cola. Investors who bought that stock at 
its peak valuation of 42 times earnings in 1973 had a loss on their 
investment for 13 long years, even though the company's earnings and 
dividends tripled between 1973 and 1986.

So it's essential to buy growth at reasonable prices.

6.	Diversify.

This is important, not only to protect a portfolio against the impact 
of the occasional big loser, but also to increase the opportunities 
to come up with real winners. The offensive aspect of diversification 
is just as important as the defensive one; spread your bets in 
seeking winners.

In 1999 many investors had a hard time keeping up with the gain in 
the market averages because they did not have a big enough stake in 
the three strongest sectors of the market: technology, which soared 
an incredible 65 percent; consumer cyclicals, which rose 20 percent; 
and energy, which was up 16 percent, surprising the many investors 
who had written off that tired, old industry.

Other investors suffered because they had too great a concentration 
in the health care field, a big winner in 1995-1998, but a temporary 
laggard in the past year.

Now, either overemphasizing 1999's strongest sectors or retreating 
from health care could well prove to be a mistake.

7.	Have realistic expectations.

Very few companies can sustain earnings and dividend growth and share 
price appreciation of better than 10 percent annually over long time 
spans. A few, like Wal-Mart and Pfizer, are able to do this, but many 
more companies are shooting stars. They experience a few years, maybe 
even a decade, of spectacular growth. And then it's back to the 
reality of single-digit earnings and dividend gains.

The average company, as measured by the Standard & Poor's 500 stock 
index, has increased its earnings per share at 7 percent annually 
over the past three decades. Therefore, a firm
that does 40 percent better than the average is able to grow at 10 
percent.

That's a very good long-term rate of growth. Compounding at 'just 10 
percent annually doubles one's money in seven years, quadruples it in 
15 years, and multiplies it eight times in 20 years. Such growth of 
capital will provide a very comfortable retirement for anyone.

                                                      Seven Ways to 
Lose Money In Stocks

1.	Buy the most popular stocks.

This is the easiest way to lose your shirt in the stock market. Many 
investors feel they have to hit a rapid series of home runs with the 
bases loaded in order to achieve favorable results. That's nonsense. 
In fact, everyone who goes chasing after the next Cisco or the 
next Intel usually ends up with plenty of tax losses every April 15.

The reason is simple. Highly popular stocks are always the ones whose 
earnings are growing most rapidly at the moment. And, in nine cases 
out of ten, such success attracts competition, so both earnings 
growth and profit margins soon shrink. Then the extremely high 
price-earnings ratio on the stock plummets. This happened to Wang 
Laboratories when it was king of the hill in word processors, to 
Digital Equipment when it dominated the minicomputer market, to Apple 
Computer when it was the number one PC producer, and to Snapple when 
it was the undisputed leader in iced-tea and fruit-flavored drinks.

2.	Try to time the market.

For a variety of reasons, mostly related to the great power of the 
market's long-term uptrend, market timers almost inevitably make 
costly mistakes from which they can never fully recover. All of the 
late 1 990s' bears are now in such a deep hole.

Studies show that even sophisticated professionals who try to time 
the market, on average have long-term returns that are one-quarter 
less than those of people who just buy good stocks and hold them 
through thick and thin, weeding out a few underachievers as they go 
along. A difference of one-quarter in average annual return may not 
seem huge, but if you compound a 25 percent differential in return 
over 25 years, you end up with 45 percent less money.

3.	Ride the strong upsurges in cyclical stocks.

Many people think they can do well trying to catch the wave of 
rising prices for cyclical stocks, such as those of automobile, 
chemical, paper and steel companies. This is extremely hard to do 
successfully, because the stocks tend to start upward when earnings 
are still very depressed and no upturn is in sight. Furthermore, 
cyclical stocks peak out early, while their earnings are still rising 
and the economic picture is bright.

All you have to do is be just a little early, or just a little late, 
on cyclicals and you lose all the advantage of their occasional 
strong advances, which are usually short-lived.

4.	Become mesmerized by yield.

Given a choice between two stocks that look similar on the surface, 
investors who need significant current income from their stock 
portfolios often favor the one with the higher dividend yield. This 
has proven costly in most areas, including the electric utility field.

Duke Energy, for example, has long been recognized as an outstanding 
power company. Its dividend yield has always been lower than that of 
most other electric companies, but Duke's earnings and dividends have 
grown quite consistently while a series of adverse changes in the 
industry has caused most electric utilities to experience flat or 
declining earnings and dividends.

So the investor who five years ago bought Commonwealth Edison, now 
called Unicom, with its 7 percent dividend yield, instead of Duke, 
which yielded just 5 percent, has suffered grievously. Unicom has cut 
its dividend 47 percent and its stock price has declined 20 percent. 
Duke, meanwhile, has raised its dividend, through annual increases, a 
total of 30 percent. And its stock price has jumped 45 percent, 
making it a far better income stock.

5.	Invest in weak competitors in hopes they will get strong.

In the business world, the rich tend to get richer, and the poor 
usually stay poor. For most of the 20th century, while General 
Electric and Westinghouse were primarily makers of electrical 
equipment, Westinghouse was always a distant second. It continued to 
lag way behind GE right up to the time
it shucked off all its traditional businesses to evolve into solely a 
broadcasting company (now merged with CBS). Similarly, the growth and 
profitability of Texas Instruments and Advanced Micro Devices have 
consistently run behind those of Intel.

6.	Buy stocks on tips.

Buying a stock without researching the idea and understanding the 
company involved is almost a sure recipe for disaster. Ignorance, in 
this case, is usually not bliss.

7. Believe the notion that this time it's different.

One example of this is the belief that baby boomers, now investing 
for retirement, will keep pouring money into stock mutual funds 
without interruption over the next 10 years, preventing a bear 
market. This is proving erroneous. In fact, the boomers already have 
shown signs of pulling back during the market's brief sinking spells 
in 1998 and 1999.

Another failure on the this time it's different syndrome was the 
widespread belief in the mid-1990s that Asian countries had found a 
way to keep breakneck economic growth, financed by huge borrowing, 
going indefinitely without any interruption. That, of course, came a 
cropper in 1997 when the rubber band got stretched too far.

Conclusion

The most successful investors are realistic optimists. They are 
realistic about the inherent weaknesses of mediocre and poor 
businesses, the volatility of the stock market, and especially about 
the wide fluctuations in investor psychology. And they are realistic 
about their inability to forecast market swings. Such realism appears 
to be in short supply these days.

At the same time, successful investors are consistently optimistic 
about the long-term growth potential of strong companies in favorably 
situated industries and the stocks of those companies.

Taken together, these characteristics make them cautious and careful, 
but not nervous, in the upper reaches of bull markets  and smart, 
eager buyers in the depths of bear markets.

title: SOURCE OF OUR POWER
words:
The story is told of a native from a remote mountain village who had 
the
opportunity to visit a large modern city for the first time. He could
not bring much home with him, and he had little money. But he was 
amazed
at the electric lights which he saw everywhere.

So he bought a sack full of electric lights bulbs and sockets with
switches so he could turn them off and on.

Arriving home he hung the light bulbs in front of his home and on his
and his neighbor's trees. Everyone watched him with curiosity and 
asked
him what he was doing, but he just smiled and said, "Just wait until
dark--you'll see."

When night came he turned on the switches, but nothing happened.

No one had told him about electricity. He did not know the light bulbs
were useless unless connected to the source of their power.

Jesus said, "Apart from me you can do nothing." There are many people
who do not know that the way they are living their lives is useless.
They got the education; they got the job; they made the family; and
bought the home but when the sun sets and night comes and they reach 
for
the switch nothing happens. They do not know that there is a source
which makes all these things light up!
topics:
SOURCE OF
STRENGTH
SPIRITUAL POWER
LIGHT BULBS
